article.headline: League title will be Baylor's first
article.linkText: Baylor wins at least share of Big 12 title
article.story:
BOULDER, Colo. (AP) -- Yelling, teaching, prodding, pleading,
coach Ceal Barry worked every bit as hard Saturday night as she has
over her last 22 years on the Colorado bench.

"I don't know any way to do it other than the way I do it,"
she said.

If only there were a few more good players for her to work with
-- like the kind who play for Baylor -- she might not be nearing the
end of her illustrious career.

Emily Niemann scored a season-high 20 points to help the
sixth-ranked Bears clinch a share of the Big 12 title for the first
time with an 84-65 victory over Barry and the overmatched Buffs.

Chameka Scott added 16 for the Bears (23-3, 13-2 Big 12), who
won their 10th straight game. At the end, they climbed over the
bench and celebrated with the small contingent of parents and
friends that followed them from Texas to see a piece of Baylor
hoops history.

"I'm a little bit emotional," Baylor coach Kim
Mulkey-Robertson said. "When you achieve a big thing in your
coaching career and for your team, you become nostalgic and you
think of all the things that took place to get to this point. I
can't tell you the thoughts going through my mind right now."

Barry knows the feeling.

Her Buffaloes (8-18, 1-14) lost for the 11th straight time, this
one coming two days after she said she would step down at the end
of the season.

Barry, 426-241 with Colorado, announced her decision on the
heels of a 43-point loss at No. 13 Texas last Wednesday that spoke
of a team that didn't have the talent to contend.

On Saturday, the Buffs scrapped and fought, only to be slowly
dissected by a team with more good shooters, ball handlers and
rebounders than what Barry could field.

Niemann hit a pair of 3-pointers and Sophia Young made three
free throws to help the Bears on a 9-2 run for a 47-32 lead at
halftime. CU never got the lead below 11 in the second half.

"They have more quickness, more weapons," Barry said. "It's
all about recruiting. It's more speed. Every loose ball, they get
to. Their hands are just quicker. But as far as heart goes, I love
my team."

In its ninth season in the Big 12, Baylor maintained a one-game
lead over Texas Tech and Texas, which both won Saturday night, with
one game left for all three teams. A win Thursday over Texas Tech,
and the Bears would win the championship outright.

"The worst you could do is share," Scott said. "I guess
that's a good feeling to go home to, to push you into this last
game."

Colorado, meanwhile, will finish last in the conference and head
to the Big 12 tournament as the 12th seed.

It's not where this program is used to being after decades spent
as a title contender and player in the NCAA tournament. But tougher
recruiting and improving competition have hurt Barry as the years
have progressed. One reason she cited for her problems was poor
attendance. The Buffs drew 3,057 Saturday night, which was about
1,000 more than average, but still only about half of what Baylor
gets each game.

Clearly, it's not for lack of trying.

An hour before tip, Barry took a microphone out to the stands to
entertain about 100 youngsters who came to watch her second-to-last
home game. When the team came onto the floor before gametime, the
coach ran not to the bench, but to the stands, where she shook
hands with boosters and chatted for a while.

Then, it was back to the sideline to watch the next in a
depressing series of losses. The 11 straight defeats added to a
school record CU broke against Texas. Before that, the Buffs hadn't
lost nine straight since 1975, their first year of varsity hoops.

Despite the loss, there were signs of a well-coached team. The
Buffs moved the ball well and took good shots. Players like Jasmina
Ilic (19 points), Jackie McFarland (17 points, 12 rebounds) and
Veronica Johns-Richardson (17 points) showed they could hang with
the best.

But Baylor, like most teams the Buffs have played this season,
simply had more good athletes, and they weren't just the biggest
names.

To wit: The Bears' leading scorers this season, Young and
Steffanie Blackmon, had below-average nights, while Scott, who
averages seven points a game, had 12 after the first 6 minutes.

And Niemann, who averages 10 a game, came off the bench and
immediately hit three quick 3-pointers. She finished 6-for-10 from
behind the arc to improve on her 50 percent shooting average for
the season.
